Package me.wobblyyyy.edt

Class ArrayIterator<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.edt.ArrayIterator<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of content that the iterator holds.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    ItrSingle<E>
    public class ArrayIterator<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements ItrSingle<E>
    Iterator used and shared by all sorts of arrays.

    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Field Detail

      • supplier

        private final ArrayableSupplier<E> supplier
        Provide a method of accessing the original arrayable element.

      • exceptionConsumer

        private final java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Exception> exceptionConsumer
        Provide a consumer for exceptions. We don't want to just throw them into the void, so we do something about it here. Yay!

      • index

        private int index
        An internal index counter. This is reset on every iteration sequence.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ArrayIterator

        public ArrayIterator​(ArrayableSupplier<E> supplier)
        Create a new ArrayIterator instance, using a supplier to supply ourselves with an Arrayable instance.
        Parameters:
        supplier - a supplier for the target Arrayable.

    • Method Detail

      • previous

        public E previous()
        Get the previous element of the DynamicArray.
        Specified by:
        previous in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Returns:
        the previous element of the DynamicArray. If there is no previous element, meaning that the element that was just used was the first element in the array, an array out of bounds exception is thrown. By default, this is handled by the iterators internal exception handler. To silence these exceptions, you can surround your code in try/catch blocks.

      • element

        public E element()
        Get the current element of the DynamicArray's array.
        Specified by:
        element in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Returns:
        the array's current element. This method won't ever throw any exceptions, unlike ItrSingle.previous() and ItrSingle.next().

      • next

        public E next()
        Get the next element in the DynamicArray's data set.
        Specified by:
        next in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Returns:
        the DynamicArray's next element. If there is no next element, meaning we've reached the end of the data set, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException is thrown, indicating that the requested index could not be found. This exception can be handled by try/catch code if you'd like to silence the exception. Otherwise, the exception's stack trace will be printed.

      • previousIndex

        public int previousIndex()
        Get the previous index.

        If this index is out of bounds, an exception is thrown. This exception can be handled by try/catch code if you so desire.

        Specified by:
        previousIndex in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Returns:
        previous index, or current index minus one.

      • index

        public int index()
        Get the current index of the array.
        Specified by:
        index in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Returns:
        the array iterator's current index.

      • nextIndex

        public int nextIndex()
        Get the iterator's next index.

        If this index is out of bounds, an exception is thrown. This exception can be handled by try/catch code if you so desire.

        Specified by:
        nextIndex in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Returns:
        next index, or current index plus one.

      • forEach

        public void forEach​(java.util.function.Consumer<E> consumer,
                    int min,
                    int max)
        Iterate over the DynamicArray's data set. Any potential exceptions that occur during the loop's executions are handled by the Itr class' default exception handler, which will print the exception's stack trace.

        For-each iteration isn't very expensive. As long as the array is not too large, running a for loop over each of the dynamic array's elements doesn't take very long at all.

        As the for loop goes through its iteration and execution, the index and current element will be updated. In addition to these values being updated, the previous() and next() methods will have their values changed. During loop execution, your consumer can access information about the array it's iterating over, such as previous, current, next elements and indexes.

        • Get next element: ItrSingle.next().
        • Get previous element: ItrSingle.previous().
        • Get current element: ItrSingle.element(). Please note: it's advised that you make use of the consumerized methods provided by the iterator class to take advantage of the consumer framework in Java.
        • Get next index: ItrSingle.nextIndex()
        • Get previous index: ItrSingle.previousIndex()
        • Get current index: ItrSingle.index()

        Specified by:
        forEach in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Parameters:
        consumer - the consumer that will consume the current element of iteration. This element is updated every iteration. Each element comes from the dynamic array's ordered set of elements.
        min - the minimum value that the for each loop should iterate over. Anything below this index value will be ignored by the loop.
        max - the maximum value that the for each loop should iterate over. Anything above this index value will be ignored by the loop.

      • forEach

        public void forEach​(java.lang.Runnable runnable,
                    int min,
                    int max)
        Iterate over the DynamicArray's data set. Any potential exceptions that occur during the loop's executions are handled by the Itr class' default exception handler, which will print the exception's stack trace.

        For-each iteration isn't very expensive. As long as the array is not too large, running a for loop over each of the dynamic array's elements doesn't take very long at all.

        As the for loop goes through its iteration and execution, the index and current element will be updated. In addition to these values being updated, the previous() and next() methods will have their values changed. During loop execution, your consumer can access information about the array it's iterating over, such as previous, current, next elements and indexes.

        • Get next element: ItrSingle.next().
        • Get previous element: ItrSingle.previous().
        • Get current element: ItrSingle.element(). Please note: it's advised that you make use of the consumerized methods provided by the iterator class to take advantage of the consumer framework in Java.
        • Get next index: ItrSingle.nextIndex()
        • Get previous index: ItrSingle.previousIndex()
        • Get current index: ItrSingle.index()

        Specified by:
        forEach in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Parameters:
        runnable - the Runnable code that will be executed for each and every one of the requested range's values. If you're only planning on using the current element value, it is suggested that you make use of the Consumer-based for each loops provided in the iterator class. For more information on these consumer based loops, look at the see tags here.
        min - the minimum value that the for each loop should iterate over. Anything below this index value will be ignored by the loop.
        max - the maximum value that the for each loop should iterate over. Anything above this index value will be ignored by the loop.
        See Also:
        ItrSingle.forEach(Consumer), ItrSingle.forEach(Consumer, int, int)

      • forEach

        public void forEach​(java.lang.Runnable runnable)
        Iterate over the DynamicArray's data set. Any potential exceptions that occur during the loop's executions are handled by the Itr class' default exception handler, which will print the exception's stack trace.

        For-each iteration isn't very expensive. As long as the array is not too large, running a for loop over each of the dynamic array's elements doesn't take very long at all.

        As the for loop goes through its iteration and execution, the index and current element will be updated. In addition to these values being updated, the previous() and next() methods will have their values changed. During loop execution, your consumer can access information about the array it's iterating over, such as previous, current, next elements and indexes.

        • Get next element: ItrSingle.next().
        • Get previous element: ItrSingle.previous().
        • Get current element: ItrSingle.element(). Please note: it's advised that you make use of the consumerized methods provided by the iterator class to take advantage of the consumer framework in Java.
        • Get next index: ItrSingle.nextIndex()
        • Get previous index: ItrSingle.previousIndex()
        • Get current index: ItrSingle.index()

        Specified by:
        forEach in interface ItrSingle<E>
        Parameters:

If you're only planning on using the current element value, it is suggested that you make use of the Consumer-based for each loops provided in the iterator class. For more information on these consumer based loops, look at the see tags here.
        See Also:
